trans-unit.source: A Connection object represents a connection with a database.

seg-source.mrk: A Connection object represents a connection with a database.

target.mrk: A Connection object represents a connection with a database.

trans-unit.source: Within the scope of one Connection, you access only a single database. (Database-side JDBC routines can allow you to access more than one database in some circumstances.) A single application might allow one or more Connections to , either to a single database or to many different databases, provided that all the databases are within the same system.

seg-source.mrk: Within the scope of one Connection, you access only a single database.

(Database-side JDBC routines can allow you to access more than one database in some circumstances.) A single application might allow one or more Connections to , either to a single database or to many different databases, provided that all the databases are within the same system.

target.mrk: Within the scope of one Connection, you access only a single database.

(Database-side JDBC routines can allow you to access more than one database in some circumstances.) A single application might allow one or more Connections to , either to a single database or to many different databases, provided that all the databases are within the same system.

trans-unit.source: With DriverManager, you use the connection URL as an argument to get the getConnection method to specify which database to connect to and other details.

seg-source.mrk: With DriverManager, you use the connection URL as an argument to get the getConnection method to specify which database to connect to and other details.

target.mrk: With DriverManager, you use the connection URL as an argument to get the getConnection method to specify which database to connect to and other details.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows an application establishing three separate connections to two different databases in the current system.

seg-source.mrk: The following example shows an application establishing three separate connections to two different databases in the current system.

target.mrk: The following example shows an application establishing three separate connections to two different databases in the current system.

trans-unit.source: Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:sample"); System.out.println("Connected to database sample"); conn.setAutoCommit(false); Connection conn2 = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:newDB;create=true"); System.out.println("Created AND connected to newDB"); conn2.setAutoCommit(false); Connection conn3 = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:newDB"); System.out.println("Got second connection to newDB"); conn3.setAutoCommit(false);

seg-source.mrk: Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:sample"); System.out.println("Connected to database sample"); conn.setAutoCommit(false); Connection conn2 = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:newDB;create=true"); System.out.println("Created AND connected to newDB"); conn2.setAutoCommit(false); Connection conn3 = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:newDB"); System.out.println("Got second connection to newDB"); conn3.setAutoCommit(false);

target.mrk: Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:sample"); System.out.println("Connected to database sample"); conn.setAutoCommit(false); Connection conn2 = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:newDB;create=true"); System.out.println("Created AND connected to newDB"); conn2.setAutoCommit(false); Connection conn3 = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:newDB"); System.out.println("Got second connection to newDB"); conn3.setAutoCommit(false);

trans-unit.source: A Connection object has no association with any specific thread; during its lifetime, any number of threads might have access to it, as controlled by the application.

seg-source.mrk: A Connection object has no association with any specific thread; during its lifetime, any number of threads might have access to it, as controlled by the application.

target.mrk: A Connection object has no association with any specific thread; during its lifetime, any number of threads might have access to it, as controlled by the application.
